title: Talon is the healthiest Assassin in the game
body:
when you hear the word Assassin, what's the First thing comes to mind? 
it's High Risk, High Reward.

reason why i think Talon is the healthiest because..


1- all of his abilities scales off Bonus AD, and they're quite high, which is needed in an assassin.
2- Talon's escape is determined by his success on his Assassination, if he could go into a teamfight and burst the AD/AP carry, then he has the chance to run away from the scene and comback after his cooldowns to round up the cleanup
3- Talon's performs wonderfully with skill-oriented players, using his Cutthroat as a counter to a skillshot, and making a counter harass is the most satisfying thing ever
4- he has a huge single target burst thanks to his damage modifier, and a good amount of AoE spells for teamfights
 
1- Talons Early Lane phase is bad, and his addiction to Flasks removes/Limits his Early damage (because he Scales off Bonus AD)
2- Talon's W Range is short, and is easily predictable (and you can only be hit with 1 Rake anyways)
3- his Mana Costs are high especially if he Tries to keep up with the other midlaners harass, and thus his bar drops quite fast
4- you can counter Talon by having the Turret's Range's line exactly on your back, so his cutthroat is rendered as a Punishment (for inexperienced Talons atleast)

now as you see you have a clear chance to put Talon under control, by being Cautious and see how he positions himself

despite it all, i still don't see where his passive fit, it's a conditional AA buff, that doesn't buff his own Q and Sheen (for obvious reasons)

instead he could be having a passive that helps him sustain in a lane
you barely AA as Talon in a burst/Teamfight so why not make it a Defensive passive? OR at the very least, make his passive grants him Bonus AD, his Flask addiction is ruining him!






--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------






**a small Edit**

 buying a Pinkward is Lethal against Talon, mainly after his Burst you will find Talon just randomly walking by, because you know, that's his only way of actually leaving, walking.
(an assassin, that simply walk? wow, right?) you have only need to place a pink, and stun him, all of his spells would be either on cooldown, or really short on range.
and no, you won't die if Talon Tried to burst you (implying your health is 100-80%), Talon CANNOT 100-0 you if BOTH of you are in Equal level and Equal amount of Farm.
do try to play Talon before you judge please, i'm not looking for a blind feedback

Remember that "healthy" is not a power level term.  It's about a champion creating good or bad gameplay for everyone in the game.  For example, Ahri is a pretty healthy champion. A 60% win rate Ahri is not something you want to play against, for sure, but it won't make you hate life half as much as a 60% win rate Talon.

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=NkvEEE0B,comment-id=0024000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-24T03:15:15.474+0000)
>
> Nobody talked about {{champion:238}} before the massive changes to mana regen, especially to {{item:3028}} , and now that every mana champion struggles more in the early game while Zed can still poke pretty comfortably, he feels unfair to play against because he doesn't pay as big a price for his ability use than most other mid laners, despite his core harass and assassination playstyle not having changed at all. 

Good take.

> I do feel Ahri has a bit too much free mobility (I'd rather her Q gave her a movement speed boost only if it hit a champion, even if the resulting boost were made a lot stronger), but overall she's in really good shape.

I don't think Ahri Q giving MS on hit ends up working out.  Ahri is a kitey character -- she's going to throw the Q and then move away.  If she gets the MS on hit, she'll be 1000 range from the target before it happens.  That's going to feel pretty irrelevant a lot of the time.

That mechanic is much more interesting on a chasing champion.

At the same time, Ahri gets to move 1000+ range away from people chasing her precisely because of her movement speed boost -- if anything, it would be easier for her to hit them while kiting them than while chasing them, since they'd be running towards her and her orb -- but right now she gets a ton of free mobility even if she completely misses her target. Right now, Ahri can throw her orb in any direction just so that she can run away faster, and I don't think that feels quite right. She's most interesting when she's moving to reposition her orb and killing her opponents as she's running away or alongside them, so she should be rewarded for staying cool and remaining accurate while getting kited. I think it's possible to give her the same amount of kiting power and still make the movespeed bonus more restricted, if only by making the bonus a lot stronger when it lands, and I think it might also solve the issue of Ahri feeling overly difficult to hit in lane.

> At the same time, Ahri gets to move 1000+ range away from people chasing her precisely because of her movement speed boost

Not really.  People didn't usually react to Old Ahri throwing Q at them by running towards her.  Disengage is pretty much baked into Ahri Q.

I think the Q buff is largely about repositioning, and I don't think the on hit version works well with that objective.

> Right now, Ahri can throw her orb in any direction just so that she can run away faster, and I don't think that feels quite right.

Seems true.

> She's most interesting when she's moving to reposition her orb and killing her opponents as she's running away or alongside them, so she should be rewarded for staying cool and remaining accurate while getting kited.

I think on cast movement speed is way better for orb manipulation than on hit.  More predictable and cleaner play patterns for both Ahri and the target.

> I think it's possible to give her the same amount of kiting power and still make the movespeed bonus more restricted, if only by making the bonus a lot stronger when it lands

I think that's a really bad idea.  Getting the same amount of power out of the less reliable MS boost is going to require a huge booster.  Like, she'd need Lulu W on hit to be as good as the current button on cast, maybe even more.  That's going to expose us to all kinds of game health risk.

> [{quoted}](name=SmokingPuffin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=NkvEEE0B,comment-id=0024000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-24T06:44:57.846+0000)
>
>I think on cast movement speed is way better for orb manipulation than on hit. More predictable and cleaner play patterns for both Ahri and the target.

The play pattern for Ahri's target (dodge the orb) and for Ahri herself (land the orb) would remain the same, so I disagree. The likeliest change would be that Ahri would benefit slightly more from landing her abilities up close than at max range, for a longer window of orb manipulation, and I think that would actually be healthier overall, since right now Ahri players are generally encouraged to land max-range Qs for instant burst. If anything, this change would make for cleaner and more predictable play patterns, because her utility would no longer be dissociated from her damage.

> [{quoted}](name=SmokingPuffin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=NkvEEE0B,comment-id=0024000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-24T06:44:57.846+0000)
>
> I think that's a really bad idea.  Getting the same amount of power out of the less reliable MS boost is going to require a huge booster.  Like, she'd need Lulu W on hit to be as good as the current button on cast, maybe even more.  That's going to expose us to all kinds of game health risk.

Is it really that bad? I mean, suppose we keep the same bonus and restrict it: would Ahri need more mobility then, and if so, how much more? This isn't about giving Ahri a pseudo-flash on Q or something, it's about tying her mobility in better to her nuke. Simply removing the decay would make the movespeed bonus a lot more powerful, without necessarily making her too strong. You're also jumping to conclusions here, as if Ahri would need to be broken OP just so that she could survive a more restrictive movement speed boost, when even just making that change without buffing her movement speed would likely still leave her as a very successful champion.

> this change would make for cleaner and more predictable play patterns, because her utility would no longer be dissociated from her damage.
 
The less predictable part ought to be obvious.  Precisely when the MS boost will activate is dependent on the opponent's movement, and the opponent doesn't know when the Q will be cast.  Trying to predict exactly where Ahri will be, even if we assume that she will keep moving in her current direction, is more challenging.  As a result, both sides are guessing more than they are currently guessing.

On the cleaner front, Ahri's play pattern no longer has a clear optimization case.  Previously, Ahri wanted to land max range Q, and the opponent wanted to avoid max range Q.  Now, Ahri gets unclear value from many ranges of landed Q.  The opponent no longer has a clear idea of where to position relative to Ahri.  Unclear optimization leads to muddled gameplay; strategy games work better when goal states are clear.

> Is it really that bad? I mean, suppose we keep the same bonus and restrict it: would Ahri need more mobility then, and if so, how much more? 

* Ahri can miss
* Ahri now must react to when the MS buff is triggered; harder to plan routes for the ball
* The MS buff occurs later.  In particular, if two mids attempt to trade skillshots and shoot at the same time, MS on hit is pretty useless for Ahri, when on cast it is very valuable.

All in all, X% MS on cast is obviously a lot better than X% MS on hit.  It would need to be 2X% or even 3X% on hit to have an equal contribution to power budget.  Making it such a high number will inevitably expose you to edge cases you don't want to design around.

Now, if your goal is to nerf Ahri, you ought to just come out and say that.  No need to beat around the bush.  If the plan is to keep her around the same power level, this change is not healthy.

> [{quoted}](name=SmokingPuffin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=NkvEEE0B,comment-id=002400000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-24T07:23:04.274+0000)
> 
> On the cleaner front, Ahri's play pattern no longer has a clear optimization case.  Previously, Ahri wanted to land max range Q, and the opponent wanted to avoid max range Q.  Now, Ahri gets unclear value from many ranges of landed Q.  The opponent no longer has a clear idea of where to position relative to Ahri.  Unclear optimization leads to muddled gameplay; strategy games work better when goal states are clear.

The reason a max-range Q is optimal is because it gives Ahri's opponent the shortest window to avoid both applications of damage. It is not optimal in the sense that Ahri something out of it that she couldn't otherwise. There are different ways of tying her mobility to her damage (you could have it apply on the first instance of damage dealt with her Q on a champion, and perhaps refresh it on a second application, for example), but ultimately doing so would still allow Ahri to use her movement speed boost to readjust her orb as she can now, assuming her orb has enough time to readjust. Max-range Qs would still give her a movement speed buff, so there's no loss in optimization. Ideally, though, her optimal Q use shouldn't be its max-range use, but rather the use of it at close to middle ranges while repositioning mid-fight, which I think can be encouraged using her mobility.

> [{quoted}](name=SmokingPuffin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=NkvEEE0B,comment-id=002400000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-24T07:23:04.274+0000)
> 
> Now, if your goal is to nerf Ahri, you ought to just come out and say that.  No need to beat around the bush.  If the plan is to keep her around the same power level, this change is not healthy.

The intent here is not to nerf Ahri in a general sense, and I don't think anyone genuinely interested in a champion takes a look at them and says "make them less powerful, doesn't matter how", or "let's buff this champion without discussing where they need buffs". I don't think the mobility on Ahri's Q should be unconditional, and so if something is getting nerfed, it's her freedom of movement using that ability, which ultimately is a nerf to her mobility by itself. If there is a way to rebalance the ability so that Ahri keeps the same amount of mobility and remains healthy, then that would be fine, and if she ends up being too weak, it would help to understand what she's specifically lacking (besides free movement, which I don't think is entirely healthy). While I don't have all the statistics in hand, a cursory look at Ahri's pick and win rates says she's pretty successful, so she'd be able to take a nerf like this fairly well. She also received mana cost nerfs recently, which could easily be mitigated or reverted in case she falls too low.

Again, you are following the reasoning that Ahri *must* have unhealthily strong mobility to remain viable, and that any buff to her raw movement speed bonus would break her, neither of which I agree with. Ahri would not have had additional mobility on her Q in the first place if it didn't have balancing levers to adjust its strength. 

> [{quoted}](name=SmokingPuffin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=NkvEEE0B,comment-id=002400000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-24T07:23:04.274+0000)
>
>The MS buff occurs later. In particular, if two mids attempt to trade skillshots and shoot at the same time, MS on hit is pretty useless for Ahri, when on cast it is very valuable.

This is one of the reasons why I think Ahri needs more restricted mobility on her Q. Unconditional mobility means Ahri can immediately (and quickly) retreat to a safe range once the throws out her Orb of Deception, making it extremely hard to hit her back or even poke her in the first place. While Ahri is meant to be evasive, she is also meant to be at her strongest when at a risky range from her enemies (which is why her Fox-Fires have a short reach and her E makes enemies walk towards her), so her evasion should come into play when she's genuinely in combat with her opponent, and not just poking them from a distance. Ahri is most interesting when she's putting herself at risk and moving around her enemies at calculatedly short distances, so I'd rather place more power there if she needs any than encourage her current max-range Q+run away poke pattern, which also carries the lowest amount of interaction with her opponent. It's this excessive safety that caused the nerfs to her mana costs in Patch 5.3:

"*It's safe to say that Ahri's return back to her kitier, mage-ier (that is a word) roots has been a success, but her new-found mobility has left her feeling a tad overbearing. For someone that skirts the edge of fights so well, Ahri wasn't taking enough risk for the reward (less dashing in, more dashing out). Forcing this fox-girl to walk the line for her guaranteed damage makes expert use of her Orb-speed and Charm, which is where we'd like to leave her feeling - skillful and satisfying to play, but vulnerable when making mistakes*"

With that in mind, I'd rather have an Ahri with more restricted mobility but better usability to her skills, than an Ahri who can poke at very little risk, but with a greater drain on her mana.

> Ideally, though, her optimal Q use shouldn't be its max-range use, but rather the use of it at close to middle ranges while repositioning mid-fight, which I think can be encouraged using her mobility.

Why is this desirable? Max range Q being optimal creates maximum counterplay and the clearest positioning minigame.

> The intent here is not to nerf Ahri in a general sense...Ahri's pick and win rates says she's pretty successful, so she'd be able to take a nerf like this fairly well.

Good design requires clear intent, and I don't hear one from you.  Is your plan to nerf Ahri, or shift power from one part of her power budget to another?  The design steps we take to follow up on the idea change based on which of these is the goal.

> If there is a way to rebalance the ability so that Ahri keeps the same amount of mobility and remains healthy, then that would be fine, and if she ends up being too weak, **it would help to understand what she's specifically lacking** (besides free movement, which I don't think is entirely healthy). 

I don't understand your question.  The nature of power budgets is that when a champion is weak, literally anything will work.  One thing we currently know is that the Q MS buff and the E damage amp are of approximately equal weight, for example.

> Again, you are following the reasoning that Ahri *must* have unhealthily strong mobility to remain viable, and that any buff to her raw movement speed bonus would break her.

I am arguing neither of those things.  I am arguing;

1. X% MS on hit is significantly weaker than X% MS on cast
2. Giving Ahri an equivalent amount of power in an % MS on hit would require something in the range of 2X-3X% MS
3. That large an MS buff exposes you to unforeseen design health consequences.

> her evasion should come into play when she's genuinely in combat with her opponent, and not just poking them from a distance. Ahri is most interesting when she's putting herself at risk and moving around her enemies at calculatedly short distances...

Ahri is intended to be very good at poking.  It's a core design value.  She is intended to spend almost all of her time poking from long range; she only closes range after poking the opponent down enough that her combo will kill if it lands.

Ahri is not Vayne, and does not have the tools to stay close to the enemy for long.  In any given two minute stretch of play, Ahri intends to be within 550 range for less than five seconds.  If you want her to want to play from that range more often, you're going to need a rework.

> It's this excessive safety that caused the nerfs to her mana costs in Patch 5.3:

The cited explanation was about W and R range nerfs, which force Ahri to get closer when she commits.  

The mana cost nerfs are simply trimming unnecessary power; they don't bring her Q cost up to the level it was on launch or during her first rework.  There's no design commentary to be found there beyond "Ahri is too strong, this will make her weaker in a relatively palatable way".

> [{quoted}](name=SmokingPuffin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=NkvEEE0B,comment-id=00240000000000000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-24T16:55:47.806+0000)
>
